questions.text: A hospital collected nasopharyngeal swabs from 1000 patients every day from onset of disease. It was found that the count of the organism was maximum on the 5th day giving maximum infectivity to 825 patients on that day. What is the period (5 days from onset of disease) known as?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:  A 

 Generation time
Explanation 
Time Periods in ID
•	Serial interval: 
–	the gap in time between onset of primary & secondary cases 
•	Infectious (communicable) period: 
–	length of time a person can transmit disease
•	Incubation period: E --------- Development of disease. 
•	Latent period: E--------- Onset of infectiousness 
–	may be shorter or longer than the incubation period
•	Generation time: E ----------- Maximal infectivity of the host
•	Window Period: E----- Lab detection of disease

Number of students immunised: 80% of 75 = 60

Number of Susceptible:75 – 60 = 15

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is C/I in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B – Varicella

Explanation

All live vaccines are C/ I in pregnancy except yellow fever (in epidemics), rabies, cholera, OPV (travel).

Influenza can be both live and killed variant.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a live vaccine?

Vaccines (Types)

  • Glyco conjugate: HiB, Pneumococccus, Meningococccus
  • Depending on the options Hepatitis B is taken as killed vaccine
  • Toxoid vaccines produce exo toxins
  • Hepatitis B vaccine was the 1st recombinant vaccine cloned in yeast

Live Attenuated Vaccines:

‘ ROME Is My Best Place To go Yet, so book a JEt ‘

  • Oral polio vaccine (OPV)
  • Measles
  • Epidemic typhus

  • Typhoid oral vaccine
  • Yellow fever
  • JE (earlier)
  • Varicella, Cholera, Rabies

questions.text: Which of the following is the National Deworming Day?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D

10th February and 10th August

Explanation

National Deworming Day (NDD) is a biannual event in India that aims to treat intestinal worm infections in children. It is celebrated on February 10th every year and August 10th  

Purpose 

  • To improve the health, nutrition, education, and quality of life of children
  • To raise awareness about the dangers of worm infections
  • To reduce absenteeism in schools

Who is treated 

  • All children aged 1–19 years, including those who are enrolled and non-enrolled in schools

How is it treated 

  • Children are given a single dose of Albendazole, a chewable tablet
  • The dose is half a tablet for children under 2 years old and a full tablet for children 2 years and older

When is it treated

  • On National Deworming Day, February 10th 
  • On a mop-up day, February 15th, for children who were unable to be treated on National Deworming Day 
  • Some states may also conduct a second round on August 10th, depending on the prevalence of worms in the state

questions.text: A Skilled Birth Attendant (SBA) delivers a baby in home and does the following. She cuts the umbilical cord with a sterile blade and ties with a new thread. She uses 2 sterile wet swabs to clean the eyes. She bathes the baby with warm water and puts the baby in skin contact of mother and advises to start Breastfeeding as earlier as possible. Which of the following is a harmful newborn care practice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Bathing the baby in warm water 
Explanation
Bathing a newborn in hot water is a harmful newborn care practice: 
Scalding: Hot water can scald a baby's skin quickly, even immediately. A safe bath temperature for babies is between 37°C and 38°C.

questions.text: Identify the deficiency in the image shown below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Zinc
Explanation
Acrodermatitis enteropathy (AE) is a rare genetic disorder that causes zinc deficiency and is characterized by skin lesions, diarrhoea, and hair loss. It's caused by a mutation in the SLC39A4 gene, which affects the body's ability to absorb zinc. 
Symptoms 
•	Eczematous, pink, scaly plaques on the hands and feet
•	Angular cheilitis
•	Paronychia
•	Generalized alopecia
•	Diarrhoea
Diagnosis 
•	A doctor will consider the patient's clinical presentation, as well as laboratory tests and histopathology.
•	A doctor may perform a plasma zinc level test, light microscopy, and electron microscopy.
Treatment 
•	Treatment involves taking oral zinc supplements, such as zinc sulphate.
•	A diet rich in zinc can help prevent recurrences.
Causes 
•	AE can be caused by inadequate zinc intake in a neonate or infant who is exclusively breastfed.
•	AE can also be caused by excessive loss of zinc through digestive fluids or increased urinary excretion.
Prevention 
To prevent recurrences, patients should take lifelong zinc supplements and eat a diet rich in zinc.

questions.solution:

Semantic barriers are problems that occur when a message is not understood or conveyed properly. Linguistic barriers are problems that occur when people use different languages, dialects, or jargon.

questions.text: In the motivational model of health education, there are 3 stages of adoption of new ideas. What is the 3rd one other than awareness and motivation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Action
Explanation
Motivational model
This model views health behaviour changes as a three-stage process of awareness, motivation, and action. 
Health motivation model
This model consists of four stages:
•	Developing a health motivation tendency 
•	Forming a health intention 
•	Initiating health-related action 
•	Persisting in actions to achieve goals 
Health promotion model
This model describes eight behaviour-specific beliefs that determine health-promoting behaviour. These beliefs include: 
•	Perceived benefits of action 
•	Perceived barriers to action 
•	Perceived self-efficacy 
•	Activity-related affect 
•	Interpersonal influences 
•	Situational influences 
•	Commitment to plan of action 
•	Immediate competing demands and preferences 
Other theories of motivation in health education include: 
a.	Maslow's hierarchy of needs theory
Proposes that people are motivated to fulfil basic needs for survival, security, social belonging, and self-esteem.
b.	Freud's psychosexual development theory
Suggests that human behaviour is motivated by unconscious desires to fulfil sexual and aggressive instincts.
